Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Central IT Operational Support for Production OpenFlow Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will deploy a pilot Software-Defined Science Network (SDSN) to interconnect research computing resources on the University of Wisconsin-Madison campus and link them to national WAN circuit fabrics via Internet2. This pilot deployment will support both Computer Science applications such as GENI WiMax experiments and prototyping activities for the University of Wisconsin?s Science DMZ between campus partner sites and the Internet.

The project will provide an opportunity to develop an operational model for the innovations promised by OpenFlow. In particular, significant effort will be expended in integrating management tools such as the UW developed web application Authorized Agent Network Tool Suite (AANTS), network monitoring tools such as PerfSONAR and traffic engineering tools such as Netflow/IPFIX. The GENI toolsets (Expedient, FOAM) will be examined for suitability for enterprise use. UW will partner with Cisco for the OpenFlow rollout. Travel budget is included for sharing and presentations of findings to the broad GENI community and non-technical user communities.

Broader Impact:
The pilot will provide an opportunity to gain experience with architectural, deployment, administrative and operational issues of OpenFlow in campus settings. Integration with WiMax as an extension of the UW production network will allow for advanced opportunities to the research and education communities such as streaming live high definition video from campus natural areas into classrooms. The PIs will report on issues and operational experience associated with the deployment. These reports and the PI?s willingness to share their experience with other universities will reduce barriers to use of GENI from campuses, establish GENI technologies and OpenFlow as building blocks for science networking, inform ongoing upgraded to campus infrastructure in support of domain sciences on campus, and via the partnership with Cisco facilitate the broader deployment of SDN technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EAGER: Central IT Operational Support for Production OpenFlow Networks provided significant upgrades to the University of Wisconsin-Madison’s wired and wireless networking infrastructure, enabling innovative, high-bandwidth applications. New OpenFlow network switches were added to facilitate dynamic allocation of circuits between campus and remote locations, allowing Wi-Fi connectivity in areas outside the campus network. Implementation of transcoding functions at different points in the campus GENI WiMAX network enabled innovative, high bandwidth applications that use WiMAX connectivity to enable live video transcoding services to users from ground vehicles, airplanes, and drones.

 

Optimizing Video Delivery For Enhancing User Experience is a project that utilized transcoding methods to get around the instability of wireless streaming of video due to limited bandwidth, high latencies and jitter.  OptVid was created as a video transcoding service that leverages the software defined networking framework installed on campus GENI rack infrastructure and video feeds made available by Digital Academic TV Network on the UW-Madison campus. The service uses both HLS and Dash streaming protocols to enable adaptive bitrate streaming across the campus WiMAX base station to different devices, operating systems, and multiple users at Wi-FI access points on campus, including students in residence halls.  

A demonstration of this implementation is available at: https://youtu.be/sMtQB_p1S6c

 

The GENI Enabling an Ecological Science Community project looked at ways of extending the UW-Madison campus network to provide connectivity to students conducting research in natural areas that are “off the grid.” Kemp Natural Resources Station is an outdoor classroom, laboratory, and weather station situated in second-growth forests of northern Wisconsin that is used by students in a number of environmental and life sciences courses at the UW-Madison and other campuses in the University of Wisconsin system. A WiMAX base station at the Kemp site allowed students basic connectivity back to the Kemp station storage resources and to cloud services such as Google docs; however, compared to the student experience on campus where data connectivity is everywhere, Kemp was still a data “dead zone,” with minimal access to compute resources that students and researchers need for automated data collection, computation, and storage in the field. The current project provided several enhancements to the Kemp site to improve data connectivity: a link between the Kemp WiMAX network and the UW-Madison GENI rack and an OpenFlow-enabled router to move traffic on the Kemp WiMAX network directly to the UW Campus network. As a result, students and researchers at Kemp were able to access the same compute, storage, and data resources available to them at the UW-Madison campus while out in the field, allowing them to move data directly to campus, run automated scripts using compute resources on GENI Rack, and access national compute and data resources all while out Kemp forest. 

Slides from a plenary presentation at GEC 21: http://groups.geni.net/geni/attachment/wiki/GEC23Agenda/Plenary/Wisconsin-GEC23-Kemp-Plenary-final_v1.pptx
